name: BIOMATERIALS
description: Biomaterials are materials used in contact with biological systems for therapeutic or diagnostic purposes. Criteria include biocompatibility (minimal adverse immune/inflammatory response), mechanical properties matching tissue-of-origin, degradation kinetics aligned with healing, and processability into desired forms. Natural biomaterials (collagen, hyaluronic acid, silk fibroin) are biocompatible and biodegradable but have batch-to-batch variability and immunogenic potential. Synthetic biomaterials offer reproducibility and tunable properties. Metals (titanium, stainless steel) provide strength for load-bearing implants but are bioinert and non-degradable; surface modification enhances osseointegration. Ceramics (hydroxyapatite, bioactive glass) are hard and bond to bone chemically but are brittle. Polymers range from biostable (PMMA, silicone for permanent implants) to biodegradable (PLA, PGA, chitosan). Hydrogels are water-rich polymeric networks mimicking soft tissue; their tunable mechanics, high water content, and mild processing suit cell encapsulation and drug delivery. Composite biomaterials combine constituents for synergistic properties—e.g., PLA/hydroxyapatite scaffolds offer polymer toughness plus ceramic bioactivity. Biocompatibility testing includes cytotoxicity (cell culture), sensitization (animal models), and systemic toxicity (hematology, blood chemistry, histology). Surface functionalization via coatings, ligands, or topography enhances cell adhesion, proliferation, and differentiation. Advanced biomaterials enable regenerative medicine and functional restoration.

name: ERGONOMICS
description: Ergonomics designs work and products fitting human bodies and minds, minimizing injury and enhancing performance. Physical Ergonomics addresses body mechanics and musculoskeletal health. Anthropometric data (heights, arm lengths, grip strengths) guides workstation dimensions and tool design. Repetitive strain injuries (RSI) result from sustained postures, repetitive motions, or forceful exertion; prevention includes task rotation, frequent breaks, and movement variety. Lower-back injuries stem from heavy lifting, twisting, and sustained flexion; training in proper mechanics and equipment (lift-assist devices, adjustable shelving) reduce risk. Workstation design specifies seat height, monitor distance, keyboard/mouse placement to maintain neutral posture. Standing work alternates with sitting to avoid prolonged static load. Hand tool design optimizes grip size, weight, and angle. Cognitive Ergonomics optimizes information presentation and task demand. Displays (digital or analog) must convey critical information clearly; color coding helps but is useless to colorblind individuals. Information density balances completeness (all needed info) against clutter (cognitive overload). Interface design follows human mental models; unexpected behavior surprises and causes errors. Feedback confirms actions; delays confuse users. Attention is a bottleneck; critical information is prominent; non-critical information is relegated to secondary displays. Situational awareness—understanding what's happening—is enhanced by integrated displays showing relationships (flight instruments in an integrated cockpit versus seven separate instruments). Workload varies; excessive workload impairs performance while underwhelming boredom causes vigilance failures. Noise, temperature, lighting affect performance; compliance with comfort and safety standards improves outcomes. Training and procedures must align with actual capabilities; policies limiting fatigue (sleep, breaks) maintain alertness. Human factors engineering applies this knowledge systematically to design, reducing errors and enhancing safety.
